metadata.title: Pythagoras Theorem
metadata.subject: Mathematics
metadata.description: Right-angled triangles, Pythagoras theorem, Pythagorean triplets

preAssessment.question: In a right-angled triangle, the side opposite to the right angle is called _____.
In â–³ABC, âˆ C = 90Â°, AC = 5 cm, BC = 12 cm. What is AB?
Which of these is a Pythagorean triplet?
A ladder of 15 m reaches a window 9 m above the ground. How far is the base from the wall?

concepts.title: Right-angled Triangle and Hypotenuse
concepts.content: A right-angled triangle has one angle equal to 90Â°. The side opposite to the right angle is the longest side, called the hypotenuse. The other two sides forming the right angle are called the base and height (or legs). Pythagoras was a Greek mathematician of the 6th century BCE.

examples.text: In â–³ABC with âˆ B=90Â°: AC is the hypotenuse (opposite to right angle)
Pythagoras of Greece (6th century BCE) proved this theorem
Also found in ancient Indian text Shulvasutra
Base and height are the two legs forming the right angle

keyPoints: Right-angled triangle has one 90Â° angle
Hypotenuse = side opposite to right angle (longest side)
Base and height = two sides forming the right angle
Named after Pythagoras (6th century BCE Greek mathematician)
Also present in ancient Indian Shulvasutra
concepts.funFact: ğŸŒ The Pythagorean theorem was known in ancient India (Shulvasutra) and Babylon long before Pythagoras â€” he was the first to formally prove it!

concepts.title: Pythagoras Theorem
concepts.content: In a right-angled triangle, the square of the hypotenuse equals the sum of squares of the other two sides. If âˆ B = 90Â° in â–³ABC, then [l(AC)]Â² = [l(AB)]Â² + [l(BC)]Â², or (hypotenuse)Â² = (base)Â² + (height)Â².

examples.text: â–³ABC with âˆ C=90Â°, AC=5, BC=12: ABÂ² = 5Â²+12Â² = 25+144 = 169 â†’ AB=13
Proof: two squares of side (b+c), arrange 4 right triangles â†’ aÂ²=bÂ²+cÂ²
Cardsheet activity: construct squares on all three sides, verify areas

keyPoints: HypotenuseÂ² = baseÂ² + heightÂ²
[l(AC)]Â² = [l(AB)]Â² + [l(BC)]Â² when âˆ B = 90Â°
Proof by square area method: aÂ² + 2bc = bÂ² + cÂ² + 2bc â†’ aÂ² = bÂ² + cÂ²
Works only for right-angled triangles
Helps find any side when other two are known
concepts.funFact: ğŸ—ï¸ Engineers use the 3-4-5 rule to check right angles in construction â€” if sides are 3, 4, 5, it's a perfect right angle!
concepts.textbookRef: Pages 87-88: Pythagoras Theorem Statement and Proof

concepts.title: Finding the Third Side
concepts.content: Given any two sides of a right-angled triangle, find the third using the Pythagorean theorem. If hypotenuse and one leg are given: missing leg = âˆš(hypÂ² - legÂ²). If both legs given: hypotenuse = âˆš(legâ‚Â² + legâ‚‚Â²).

examples.text: Right triangle: find x from hypotenuse and one side

keyPoints: Hypotenuse = âˆš(baseÂ² + heightÂ²)
Missing leg = âˆš(hypotenuseÂ² - known legÂ²)
Always identify which side is the hypotenuse first
Use square root after applying the theorem
Real-world: ladder problems, height problems
concepts.funFact: ğŸ  A 15m ladder reaching 9m height: the base is exactly 12m from the wall â€” a classic 3-4-5 right triangle scaled by 3!

concepts.title: Pythagorean Triplets
concepts.content: Three natural numbers form a Pythagorean triplet if the square of the largest equals the sum of squares of the other two. For example: (3,4,5) since 3Â²+4Â²=5Â². If sides of a triangle form a Pythagorean triplet, the triangle is right-angled.
keyPoints: Pythagorean triplet: aÂ²+bÂ²=cÂ² for natural numbers a, b, c
c must be the largest number
Any triangle whose sides form a triplet is right-angled
Multiples of triplets also work: (6,8,10), (9,12,15)
concepts.funFact: ğŸ§± Egyptian builders used ropes knotted in a 3-4-5 ratio to create perfect right angles for pyramids â€” Pythagorean triplets in action!

concepts.title: Verifying Right-angled Triangles
concepts.content: To check if a triangle is right-angled: check if the square of the largest side equals the sum of squares of the other two sides. If (largest)Â² = (otherâ‚)Â² + (otherâ‚‚)Â², the triangle is right-angled at the vertex opposite the largest side.
keyPoints: Check: (largest side)Â² = (sideâ‚)Â² + (sideâ‚‚)Â²
If equal â†’ right-angled triangle
If not equal â†’ not right-angled
The right angle is at vertex opposite the largest side (hypotenuse)
Non-Pythagorean triplets: (2,4,5), (4,5,6), (1.5,1.6,1.7)
concepts.funFact: ğŸ“ Surveyors still use the 3-4-5 method with measuring tapes to create right angles when setting up boundaries!

test.question: In â–³ABC, âˆ C = 90Â°, l(AC) = 5 cm and l(BC) = 12 cm. What is l(AB)?
test.explanation: ABÂ² = ACÂ² + BCÂ² = 5Â²+12Â² = 25+144 = 169. AB = âˆš169 = 13 cm.

test.question: A ladder of 15m reaches a window 9m above the ground. What is the base distance?
Do (7, 24, 25) form a Pythagorean triplet?
test.explanation: 7Â²+24Â² = 49+576 = 625 = 25Â². Yes, they form a Pythagorean triplet.

test.question: Is the triangle with sides 8, 15, 17 right-angled?
In â–³LMN, âˆ M = 90Â°, l(LM) = 12cm and l(LN) = 20 cm. What is l(MN)?
test.explanation: LN is hypotenuse. MNÂ² = LNÂ²-LMÂ² = 400-144 = 256. MN = 16 cm.

test.question: Is (9, 40, 41) a Pythagorean triplet?
test.explanation: 9Â²+40Â² = 81+1600 = 1681 = 41Â². Yes, it is a Pythagorean triplet.

test.question: Is the triangle with sides 11, 12, 15 right-angled?
test.explanation: 11Â²+12Â² = 121+144 = 265 â‰  225 = 15Â². Not a Pythagorean triplet â†’ not right-angled.

test.question: In âˆ†PQR, âˆ P = 90Â°, l(PQ) = 24cm, l(PR) = 10cm. What is l(QR)?
test.explanation: QR is hypotenuse. QRÂ² = PQÂ² + PRÂ² = 576+100 = 676. QR = 26 cm.

test.question: The side opposite to the right angle in a right-angled triangle is _____.
test.explanation: The hypotenuse is the side opposite the right angle â€” it is always the longest side.

test.question: Which triplet is NOT Pythagorean?
test.explanation: 2Â²+4Â² = 4+16 = 20 â‰  25 = 5Â². So (2,4,5) is NOT a Pythagorean triplet.

keyConcepts: Named after Pythagoras (6th century BCE); also in Indian Shulvasutra
Hypotenuse: side opposite right angle, always the longest side
Finding third side: hyp=âˆš(bÂ²+hÂ²) or leg=âˆš(hypÂ²-legÂ²)
Pythagorean triplets: natural numbers where cÂ²=aÂ²+bÂ²
commonMisconceptions: Theorem works for all triangles â€” FALSE, only right-angled triangles
The hypotenuse is always the base â€” FALSE, it's the side opposite the right angle
(2,4,5) is a Pythagorean triplet â€” FALSE, 4+16=20â‰ 25
Any multiple of a right triangle is not right-angled â€” FALSE, multiples of triplets also form right triangles
realWorldExamples: Ladder problems: height reached vs base distance from wall
Construction: 3-4-5 rope trick for right angles
Ramps and slopes: calculating incline length
Cricket pitch: measuring diagonal of rectangular pitch

formulas.explanation: Pythagoras theorem: hypotenuseÂ² = sum of squares of other two sides
Find hypotenuse when both legs are known
Find a leg when hypotenuse and other leg are known

interactiveElement.title: Build the Formula!
interactiveElement.description: Arrange the pieces to form the correct mathematical expression.

data.explanation: In a right-angled triangle, the square of the hypotenuse (c) equals the sum of squares of the other two sides.

textbookExercise.instructions: Memorize these exam-style answers to maximize scoring in textbook-focused assessments.

longAnswers.question: In â–³ABC, âˆ C = 90Â°, l(AC) = 5 cm and l(BC) = 12 cm. What is l(AB)?
longAnswers.modelAnswer: According to Pythagoras Theorem, in a right-angled triangle, the square of the hypotenuse is equal to the sum of the squares of the other two sides. Here, â–³ABC is a right-angled triangle with âˆ C = 90Â°, so AB is the hypotenuse. Therefore, l(AB)Â² = l(AC)Â² + l(BC)Â² = 5Â² + 12Â² = 25 + 144 = 169. Taking the square root of both sides, we get l(AB) = 13 cm.
keyPoints: Apply Pythagoras theorem: hypotenuseÂ² = baseÂ² + heightÂ².
Identify AB as the hypotenuse since it is opposite to âˆ C (90Â°).
Substitute the given values: 5Â² + 12Â² = 169.
Find the square root to get l(AB) = 13 cm.

longAnswers.question: A ladder of 15m reaches a window 9m above the ground. What is the base distance?
longAnswers.modelAnswer: Let the ladder form the hypotenuse of a right-angled triangle with the wall and the ground. The length of the ladder (hypotenuse) is 15m and the height of the window from the ground is 9m. According to Pythagoras Theorem, baseÂ² + heightÂ² = hypotenuseÂ², which gives baseÂ² + 9Â² = 15Â². Therefore, baseÂ² = 225 - 81 = 144, meaning the base distance from the wall is 12m.
keyPoints: Represent the situation as a right-angled triangle.
The ladder acts as the hypotenuse (15m) and the wall as the height (9m).
Use Pythagoras theorem to find the missing side: baseÂ² = 15Â² - 9Â².
Calculate the square root of 144 to find that the base distance is 12m.

longAnswers.question: In â–³LMN, âˆ M = 90Â°, l(LM) = 12cm and l(LN) = 20 cm. What is l(MN)?
longAnswers.modelAnswer: In the right-angled â–³LMN, âˆ M = 90Â°, making LN the hypotenuse. By Pythagoras Theorem, the square of the hypotenuse equals the sum of squares of the other two sides: l(LN)Â² = l(LM)Â² + l(MN)Â². Substituting the given values, 20Â² = 12Â² + l(MN)Â², which gives 400 = 144 + l(MN)Â². Therefore, l(MN)Â² = 400 - 144 = 256, and taking the square root gives l(MN) = 16 cm.
keyPoints: Identify LN as the hypotenuse since it is opposite the 90Â° angle.
State Pythagoras theorem: l(LN)Â² = l(LM)Â² + l(MN)Â².
Substitute known values to get 20Â² = 12Â² + l(MN)Â².
Solve for l(MN) by taking the square root of 256 to get 16 cm.

longAnswers.question: In âˆ†PQR, âˆ P = 90Â°, l(PQ) = 24cm, l(PR) = 10cm. What is l(QR)?
longAnswers.modelAnswer: For the right-angled âˆ†PQR with âˆ P = 90Â°, QR is the hypotenuse. According to Pythagoras Theorem, the square of the hypotenuse equals the sum of the squares of the other two sides, so l(QR)Â² = l(PQ)Â² + l(PR)Â². Substituting the given lengths, l(QR)Â² = 24Â² + 10Â² = 576 + 100 = 676. Taking the square root of both sides, we find that l(QR) = 26 cm.
keyPoints: Recognize QR as the hypotenuse opposite to âˆ P.
Apply Pythagoras theorem: l(QR)Â² = l(PQ)Â² + l(PR)Â².
Calculate the sum of squares: 24Â² + 10Â² = 676.
Find the square root to determine l(QR) = 26 cm.

longAnswers.question: Do the lengths 9 cm, 40 cm, and 41 cm form a right-angled triangle?
longAnswers.modelAnswer: In any triangle, if the square of the longest side equals the sum of the squares of the other two sides, the triangle is right-angled. Here, the longest side is 41 cm, and its square is 41Â² = 1681. The sum of the squares of the other two sides is 9Â² + 40Â² = 81 + 1600 = 1681. Since 1681 = 1681, the sides form a Pythagorean triplet, confirming it is a right-angled triangle.
keyPoints: Identify the longest side as the potential hypotenuse.
Calculate the square of the longest side (41Â² = 1681).
Calculate the sum of the squares of the other two sides (9Â² + 40Â² = 1681).
Compare the results to verify if they are equal, proving it is a right-angled triangle.
